TopicTitle: Devnote Tuesday: is it March already?

Articles.Content:
> 
> **Felipe (HarvesteR):** Work on the fairings is nearing completion now....
> 
> This should allow you to build Apollo-like designs, where the LEM was housed inside the interstage fairing, among many other possibilities.

!!! That is amazing. You have no idea how much this means to me.

I have another question: will the "old" model of Mk1-2 and Mk1 Inline will get a little bit of "overhaul" similar to the one that happened to Mk1 cockpit? I think that would be nice to see this along the new IVA ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

Question: If we have interstage fairings available, can we just do away with the automatic engine fairings? They're a hindrance as often as not (looking at you, LV-N\*) and it sounds like the interstage system is more flexible (can hide clusters or look good with mismatched tank/engine sizes).

\*I can't stay mad at you, LV-N, even if your fairing is terrible. Curse your seductively high Isp!

> 
> Actually:

I hope that`s Unity 5 AND 64bit.

All the stuff being added I have 0 interrest in as I like my soup and only goes at the expense of mods I want to use that are pushing memory usage as it is.

Not to mention, I want to play with max graphics and highest Astronomer`s Interstellar textures again ![:(](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_sad.gif)

All Hail Mu... Memory leak destroyer!

I very much appreciate your efforts and look forward to seeing the effects.

OOoh the Running Man. Richard Dawson's last movie role. Neither King nor Schwarzenegger were particularly pleased with Glaser's take on the story.

Lots of this.

Looks good, glad to see the progress being made, especially with the aerodynamic and heat systems and the focus on bugfixing and optimization. Still think that jumping straight to 1.0 from alpha (.90 wasn't a real beta, not with the number of new systems planned for the next update) isn't the best decision, hopefully Squad will prove me wrong and release an amazing 1.0 that is balanced and bug free.

Kind of disappointed with the secret project, not because being able to upload a craft file and have it 3D printed isn't awesome but because the price (minimum $99) is way too high for a fragile model with no moving parts. Now if there was a KSP building set where I could snap the parts together and rebuild the rocket whenever I felt like it (and go out and buy new parts to add to it) I would be all over it for that price. At least the KSP papercraft templates let me build a rocket however I want (including multiple stages) for a much better price.

Four pages already? I need to get it together!

I liked reading everything in these devnotes, but especially that you're fixing memory leaks and doing further optimization. That is so great! ![:D](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_cheesy.gif)

Would still love to hear something, anything, about how the shmelta-vee report is being handled. Is it displayed only in the vehicle editor, in flight, or both? Can it display individual shmelta-vee levels for individual stages, or just the total for the vehicle? Can it display different shmelta-vee values for vacuum and different atmospheres?

How about a note discussing how and why various Squad devs might have come to reverse your position on shmelta-vee?

When it comes to affecting how players design their craft, this rhymes-with-shmelta-vee whatsit seems like it'll be a *lot* more important than a reminder about parachutes. I'd love to read your thoughts about it.

When you 3D print a .craft file out, will the decouplers and docking ports be attachable and detachable parts in some way (maybe interlocking bits with a quarter-twist to lock in place or something like that) or will the whole .craft be one single inseparable piece?
I'm trying real hard to not get excited by inferring an imminent release date from the blurb about Unity 5 not being implemented in 1.0.

> 
> Question: If we have interstage fairings available, can we just do away with the automatic engine fairings?

I'd like this as an option, if I can keep the default interstage fairings, because they are "free" - adding a custom interstage fairing will cost an additional part. I'd really like it, if interstage would let me easily put a 3.75m Kerbodyne stage, below a 2.5m stage that is powered by 4 aerospikes in a quad adapter. And have structural integrity between them ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)
Fixing memory leaks? Thank Jupiter for that.

> 
> I'm trying real hard to not get excited by inferring an imminent release date from the blurb about Unity 5 not being implemented in 1.0.

I'm not sure you can read too much into that, about release dates. Updating to a new Unity version would be a non-trivial task. "Close enough to the release date to not to want to upgrade Unity" isn't a very high bar. Even if the release was still a month or so off that would still be too close. Updating Unity is likely to create a slew of hard to notice problems and bugs and even if it worked well, it would still invalidate any QA work that has already been done, having to start the testing over from scratch just to be sure.

Honestly, I feel like the release of Unity 5 is all the more reason to delay 1.0 by one release (have an intermediate 0.95 or 0.99 release). As much progress as is being made (great stuff, by the way ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)), it is important to remember that there is no real rush. Thanks For Reading! ![:D](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_cheesy.gif)

> 
> Honestly, I feel like the release of Unity 5 is all the more reason to delay 1.0 by one release

I agree that 1.0 should be delayed until after at least one or two more beta releases, but I'm not sure that integrating Unity 5 would be beneficial at this point. As we've seen already Unity has a fairly large share of its own bugs that the dev team has likely developed workarounds for, and with a major new engine release (not just an incremental bugfix) there are likely to be many new bugs in Unity that will require another incremental bugfix. There's nothing in the current version of Unity that's really holding the game back (64-bit windows support notwithstanding), it's best at this point for Squad to focus on finishing their game (especially balance and bugfixing) and wait for any major issues with Unity 5 to be worked out before updating.

> 
> I think when you are starting out with KSP, "experiential learning" is a fun part of the game. But, once players graduate beyond Kerbin orbit, they start wanting more help from the game, to accomplish complex tasks without reverting back to the VAB 20 times.

Yes, knowing that you have enough TWR and dV to get off of Tylo or Eve is very valuable data, saving lots of game time in failed missions. But the Mun and Minmus can done "by the seat of your pants"
We need a Hail Mu emoticon. Cookie for whomever gets the reference ![;)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_wink.gif)
Any chance water lag will be fixed in 1.0?
Squad seems pretty set on this whole 1.0 thing no matter what the Official Forum Community thinks. As much as we'd all love Unity 5 for the release.

> 
> Squad seems pretty set on this whole 1.0 thing no matter what the Official Forum Community thinks.

Squad hasn't ever not been 'pretty set' to do as it sees fit. To quote regex - "dude, *it's squad*."

Whilst input is sometimes sought, it's still their baby to grow as they see fit. Unity 5 has been delayed more often than the second coming of cthulhu; that and I cannot even *begin* to fathom why people are so dead-set that the 1.0 version should run on unity 5.0, which is almost certainly going to be a veritable bug fest; lets release the game to the world as gold, on a major engine version release. I'm sure that will end well. ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

Better to give the engine a chance to stabilize first, sort out the loose ends, clean up longstanding bugs and memory issues, *then* commence to migrate code across when you know it's mostly 'done'. 

We've had quite enough game breaking bugs, so I am far more pleased that the focus has been to 'finish' a lot more of what was started, and a big bug cleanup done, than embracing a world of pain that 5.0 is almost certain to bring with it, early on.
